Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Kelly Swarts

Proposal Number: 1612158

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Kelly Swarts is "Direct estimation of maize population dynamics and targets of selection from near domestication to the present from archaeological samples in Mexico." The host institution for this fellowship is the Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology, and the co-sponsoring scientists are Drs. Hern√°n Burbano and Johannes Krause.

This project focuses on domestication and adaptation of maize (corn) to better understand the basis for modern maize diversity. Maize is a globally important commodity crop plant, found everywhere from arid deserts to lowland tropics to northern Europe. Non-agricultural peoples in central Mexico first identified the biological potential in teosinte (Zea mays ssp. parviglumis) nearly 10,000 years ago and began the selection process of transforming a wild grass into a dependent crop plant. This process continues to the present, as people carried maize first across the Americas and then the world. Each of these peoples has imposed their values and priorities onto maize, persistently selecting favorable and adapted varieties, and ultimately generating the remarkable biological and morphological diversity found globally in maize. The Fellow?s research addresses the arc of domestication and adaptation, integrating ancient genomics, maize genetics, and archaeology, to better understand the basis for modern maize diversity through maize evolution near the center of origin in Mexico. The Fellow is combining publicly available databases of modern maize with DNA derived from archaeological maize macroremains recovered from sites near the putative center of maize origin (dating from nearly 6,000 years ago to the present), to answer the following questions: 1) How strong was the domestication bottleneck and what were the effective population sizes of early maize?; 2) Can we refine the geographical region of domestication using archaeological populations?; 3) Which phenotypic traits and functional classes of the genome were targeted for selection and how did these change over time?; and 4) Can we differentiate the effects of the changing environment, culture, and heritable genetic variance in ancient maize phenotypes?

The Fellow is being trained to be proficient in the methods of extraction and analysis of ancient DNA, and to integrate these data with population and quantitative genetic analyses. Addressing maize evolution as a culturally-situated process is of societal importance because understanding the genetic impacts of past decisions can help us predict the genetic impacts of human actions going forward, for this globally important crop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ancient DNA provides a unique opportunity to directly observe ancestral populations within their cultural and environmental context. Maize (Zea mays ssp. mays) is arguably the most important New World domesticate, both archaeologically and within modern agronomic systems. This grant focused on publicly held archaeological populations from dry cave shelters across the Americas from the southwest US to Chile, dating from ~6,000 years to the present (Figure 1). Genotypic information allows us to estimate population parameters and genome structure directly to elucidate population and genome dynamics across maize improvement. Combined with insights from modern populations, ancient samples allow us to parse the role of time, culture and the environment in shaping the maize genome and trait evolution.

Over the two years of grant cycle, we evaluated two hundred and two samples overall in a clean room at the University of Tuebingen. All were extracted using archaeologically specific protocols to retain small fragments (Gutaker et al., 2017). Double stranded libraries (Meyer and Kircher, 2010; Kircher et al., 2012) were generated for testing proportion of endogenous maize content and authenticating age based on deaminated bases  (C->T on the 5', and G->A on the 3'), which increase with age and preservation conditions. Across all samples,

?      5' misincorporations for samples with at least 1000 reads mapping to maize is 3-24%

?      9-76% of reads are mappable to any NCBI genome (Herbig et al., 2016)

?      0-89% of mappable reads map to Zea, with a median of 1%

?      Median fragment length ranges from 18-71 bp, with an average length of 45 bp

We generated GATK variant calls for high endogenous ancient samples from 4,000 year old McEuen Cave in Arizona after enzymatically correcting for deaminations  (Briggs et al., 2010), including modern inbreds, landraces and teosintes, with Tripsacum dactyloides as an outgroup. A major insight of this activity is the extent of the sensitivity of the GATK pipeline to depth of coverage (Figure 2), and all sequences below 15X were excluded for discovery SNP calling. Because even after deamination correction there is still a residual misincorporation at the first two bases for ancient reads, we developed an algorithm in the context of the Picard Tools suite (Picard Tools - By Broad Institute), DownweightDeaminations, that can flexibly downweight base-quality scores for potentially deaminated bases. Additionally, a de novo GBS build balanced for landraces from across the Americas (~6,000 individuals), teosinte (~2,000 individuals) and inbred lines (~4,000 individuals) is ongoing, pending the addition of the final panel of landraces from the CIMMYT Seeds of Discovery panel (Figure 3).

Training Activities

The primary training goal of the grant was to become fluent in ancient genomic molecular and bioinformatics approaches and this has been accomplished. Additional training activities have included five invited talks and two presentation of posters.

I have accepted a tenure-track/junior group leader position at the Mendel Institute/Max F. Perutz Laboratory in Vienna, Austria, after four in-person interviews (UC - Berkeley, UC - Davis, the University of Arizona). Miguel Vallebueno, a visiting graduate student who I trained in ancient extraction and library protocols, will join me as a postdoc in March to continue analyses on the ancient maize samples generated during this granting period.

Outreach Activities

Primary outreach activities include a lecture for the public and meetings with archaeologists and members of the Hopi and Zuni tribes in Northern Arizona that took place in November 2018 in Cortez, Colorado. These public talks help inform the public about the potential information gain from ancient genomics, and provided opportunities to discuss future projects, including a recently funded grant from the History Colorado State historical fund (2019-M2-001) to build a database focused on contextualizing archaeological maize in the Southwest US. Additionally, I contributed to a radio piece by Cally Carswell, aired on NPR, about the history and importance of maize for native groups called ?Mesa Verde Voices ? Ancient Corn, Modern Questions?.
